part.caption: Benchmarks of various build tools

ul.li: Autotools versions were autoconf 2.61, automake 1.10.1, libtool 1.5.26
Tool chain versions were gcc 4.2.4, binutils 2.18.0

part.part:
The benchmarks were generated with the script. The script produces reproductible seeded-random setups. All these tests were run on the same gen-bench output, but each copied to its own directory to ensure they don't interfere with each others, i.e.
./gen-bench bench 50 100 15 5 cp -R bench bench-make cp -R bench bench-wonderbuild cp -R bench bench-waf cp -R bench bench-autotools cp -R bench bench-scons
This gen-bench invocation generates 10000 tiny interdependent C++ source and header files, to be built into 50 static libs.
The autotools generated only one makefile with everything (no recursive make invocation), and C++ dependencies were tracked with gcc while compiling; libtool was enabled, even for building static libs.
The toy makefiles generated were recursive, and C++ dependencies were tracked using the makedepend X utility.
Waf and scons used a full-featured custom preprocessor to scan C++ dependencies.
Waf is also able to use gcc's generated deps as a side-effect of compilation (-MMD option), but i didn't measure it yet.
Wonderbuild used either gcc's generated deps as a side-effect of compilation (-MMD option), or a custom dumb include scanner, with no condition nor macro evaluation.
Waf's parallel algorithm was set to "normal" (faster than "max parallel").
Waf and scons were tuned to use file timestamps comparisons rather than md5 sums (for waf, in Utils.py, def h_file(filename): return str(os.stat(filename).st_mtime) ).
Scons' automatic fetching of source files from SCMs was disabled, cache of implicit deps was enabled, built target cache was disabled, copying of source files to the build dir was disabled.
All tools were configured to use the same compiler flags (-g -O0 -Wall -DBENCH -DBENCH_LIB=x -Idir), and to produce static libs only.
Configuration time was not counted (altough it's not really clear for scons).
All tests were run at least seven times (first run not counted) and the average taken (sorry, didn't measure incertitude). Initial builds for scons and autools were not run seven times as they take AGES.
All tools were run with silent/quiet option and/or > /dev/null.
All tests were run with 4 jobs on the same quad core system, ext2 filesystem on lvm/dmraid0 device, linux, gcc's C++ compiler.
The command lines used to run the tests were the following (of course configurations were not rerun every time, see for the actual run script):
# toy makefiles time make -C bench-make -r --jobs=4 --silent
# wonderbuild ( cd bench-wonderbuild && time ../../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --jobs=4 --silent )
# waf ( cd bench-waf && ../../waf-light configure && (time ../../waf/waf-light --jobs=4) > /dev/null )
# autotools ( cd bench-autotools && autoreconf --install --symlink && mkdir build-autotools && cd build-autotools && ../configure --disable-shared CXXFLAGS= && (time make -r --jobs=4 --silent) > /dev/null )
# scons time SCONS_LIB_DIR=$(pwd)/../scons/src/engine python ../scons/src/script/scons.py -C bench-scons --no-cache --jobs=4 --silent -Q
Wonderbuild is a work-in-progress and not ready for production. Currently, it aims at building C++ code only, it's not documented, and lacks some essential features. If you need a complete and fast build tool, i suggest you try waf.
However, if you have an insterest in developping build tool systems, you can try wonderbuild with this benchmark with:
svn co https://psycle.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/psycle/branches/bohan/wonderbuild --ignore-externals cd wonderbuild/benchmarks ./gen-bench bench 50 100 15 5 cd bench time ../../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # initial full build time ../../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # no-op rebuild touch lib_17/class_17.h && time ../../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # small partial rebuild touch lib_17/*.h && time ../../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # big partial rebuild
